A correction is needed about Americans and biscuits. We have them with just butter quite often; sometimes with jam, preserves, or jelly; sometimes with gravy. While gravy is used by all areas of the U.S., it is a little more prevalent in the south. Me personally, I'm from the North, and love them with gravy but only have it rarely at restaurants. I most often just add a butter. We have scones too, and they Are DEFINITELY different from our biscuits. The scones we have are hard and usually a bit sweet so you can dunk them in breakfast drinks like coffee. The biscuits are typically soft and layered and not sweet but savory.

First, love the whole video. However, there's no such thing as an "American" accent. Not anymore. Just like any large, multicultural nation, we have many dialects & accents. I didn't know the Olympic swimmer Michael Phelps was from Baltimore until I watched him being interviewed. For example, there's a big different between a Downeast Maine accent & a northern Mainer (Aroostook County) where many folks have a bit of a Quebec-French dialect. Northern Florida sounds completely different from the Gold Coast, which has a hodgepodge of Caribbean & Latin American migrants plus many Canadian & Yankee snowbirds, at least until Trump scared them away. Cajuns & Creoles are another contrast, east versus west in southern Louisiana. Michigan versus Minnesota: big diff. Southern California versus the "Inland Empire." Many Brits may know the southern Cali sound thanks to American TV & Hollywood. I'm from NY; tons of accents here. What these kids did was to scrub out their British public school affect & produce a great but generic US voice. Especially the first "bloke." They don't speak like that in Alabama, Ohio, or Alaska. Many young folks scrub out their rural accent once they move to the "big metropolis" for school or work. No one wants to sound like a slick hick. It's too bad, really.

Thereâ€™s a reason why Americans donâ€™t usually have or use electric kettles. Americans cut or break those biscuits in half, and not only pour gravy over them but and assortment of other delicious things ie: jams, preserves, jelly (which is not Jello) honey, and no doubt a multitude of other personal favorites. Have a friend that splits them, places a tomato slice and bacon or a sausage patty on each piece and places them in the oven until the cheese melts and has a bit of color. They are also used to make breakfast sandwiches with fried eggs, bacon or sausage and cheese at home, fast food joints and restaurants. They make great cinnamon rolls, bread pudding and strawberry shortcake. And donâ€™t forget the overindulgent chocolate gravy. There is a multitude of uses for biscuits. They are simply just limited by oneâ€™s mind.  Take chicken for example, instead of maybe 10 ways to serve it, Americans, have thousands+. And, people are still creating new recipes. It just may be an obsession we have with â€œchoicesâ€. And, the fact that most of us enjoy eating and trying new foods, new recipes. Americanâ€™s are just more creative and experimental in the kitchen. Where Brits are for the most part traditionalists when it comes to food, which is fine. Iâ€™m just glad Iâ€™m American, I love choices, lots and lots of variety. lol.

Americans use "I'm in a bit of a pickle too" but in a very different way. It's actually a BASEBALL term where the batter is caught between two bases (typically third base and home plate) and the two defending players are trying to tag him out, that's a baseball term called PICKLE, but Americans don't typically use it in every day life. On occasion you'll hear on in that context but it's a baseball term. Have you not seen the movie SANDLOT where Hamilton "The Great Hambino" Porter yells PICKLE when The Jet is caught between third and home? We love our baseball, and hockey..... and..... sadly football

OKâ€¦ About those little counter cluttering electric tea kettles that apparently the British canâ€™t live withoutâ€¦ Some Americans do have them, but not very many. We DO have tea kettles, though. They just arenâ€™t â€œElectricâ€. They are a regular metal teakettle, and we take the lid off of them fill them with fresh cold water, replace the lid, and put them on a burner on our range top, or cooktop and bring the water to a boil. Me personally, I like tea, I use loose tea, and bagged tea and 99% of the time I make my tea in an actual teapotâ€¦ A ceramic teapot, of which I have several and one of them was actually made in England. I take the boiling water from the stove burner And pour it into my teapot over the tea leaves and allow the tea to steep for a few minutes and then enjoy it either hot or iced.   I have no desire to ever buy an electric water warming device to sit on my counter simmering the water till itâ€™s just polluted with mineral deposits. No thanks. Iâ€™ll stick with my old-fashioned tea kettle and using fresh water every single time.

How to make proper tea-  Boil a pot of water(or a kettle) with the lid on, to keep the heat inside, at high temperature.  Once boiled, take your cup, be it a thermos to keep it warm, or an average mug or cup so it can cool down, and put your tea bag(s) in the cup, then pour the water into the cup from the kettle or pot.  Wait for 4 minutes for it to steep.  Once steeped, wrap the string around the teabag on a spoon, and squeeze the tea out into the cup, then throw away the teabags(or save them for later, if that's your cup of tea). Then add a bucket of sugar, and your tea is ready!   Btw a good tea blend would be vanilla caramel mixed with peppermint and toasted coconut with almond bark. Also with a bucket of sugar.

@olivia8924 Secondary School.  Order goes:  Reception (4-5) Primary School (5-11) Secondary School (11-16) 6th Form/College (16-18) University/Further Education  Education is mandatory up to 16 (GCSEs). Its so shocking to me that a biscuit/scone with gravy is so repulsing to them

About the scone/biscuit: well, I'm from a region in Brazil where some moms make a type of scone called "bisque". You don't find them in markets or snack bars, but only in some homes, where there's someone who has the "secret" recipe. Loved it as a child. Years ago, I found out this "bisque" had been brought to Brazil by American immigrants during civil war. They were confederates who were running away and brought some southern habits. So, it hit me that "bisque" was originally "biscuit", pronounced in a Brazilian way, and every mom that knew how to bake them was an American descendant or a friend of an American descendant. Then I came to the UK and discovered "scone". I thought, "hey it tastes like bisque". Now I know that bisque is the Brazilian version of biscuit, which is the American version of scone. Love them all, btw!

British BBQ, and for that fact, many places in the world that call something BBQ, is just a synonym for grilling. There is a difference between BBQ and Grilling here in the US, especially where I from, The South. BBQ is lowheat and the heat is often not directly sourced, like in a box to the side and generally takes a long time. Grilling is high heat and shorter. If you ask me to go to a Backyard BBQ and I see Hotdogs and Burgers, firstly, thank you for the food, secondly, thats not BBQ.

British "B-B-Q" with sausages and burgers or whatever...  is...  not... Barbecue.  B-B-Q, or even B-B-Que, sure.  But *Barbecue*...  it is *not*.  Barbecue is an entirely different kind of cuisine in and of itself, that cannot be explained in a Youtube Comments thread, without said thread hitting some arbitrary character limit!    Also, the English Breakfast there, I'm American and I can tell you that I would eat every single bite of that plate...  except those cruddy, pathetically sub-par, ketchup beans.  Make my beans Molasses Baked Beans, or some kind of hardier Baked Beans...  not that Bri'ish ketchup beans malarke;, those things aren't even fit for children to eat.  Nasty.    Also, the kids grossing out over the Biscuits and Gravy...  ya'll still eat Chipped Beef on Toast.  Guess where we got our Sausage Gravy (also known as Saw Mill Gravy) and Scone like Biscuits from.  From Chipped Beef on Toast sucking so badly, so we made it differently and it is superior to your Chipped Beef on Toast.  :-)    Lastly, we do have Kettles here in America.  Some folks have gotten electric kettles, like Jet Boil for example, but that's because they have experienced them in Britain and bought one online.  The majority of houses in America do not have a kettle...  unless...  you are in The South.  Down here in The South, many homes down here do have a kettle...  a stove top kettle.  We heat it on the stove top/range/cooktop/hob/burner/whatever you call it there.  Most of us down here don't have a dedicated kettle just to sit on the countertop, and most folks that drink hot tea down here are old Southerners, and most live in places like Charleston or Savannah where Hot Tea was always a staple of folks' lives there.  Hot Tea has fallen out of style for most of the USA in favor of coffee or (*shudder*) soda/pop/soft drinks.  However, some of us ain't a bunch of heathens and still like hot tea now and a again...  or quite often in some of our cases.  For some of us, hot tea is our coffee, because some of us hate the taste of coffee.  But yeah, most of The USA doesn't do Hot Tea.  Your jerk of a king way back in the 1700's taxing it to the point no one could afford it ruined that, and then we found coffee.  That's why.  The Boston Tea Party changed more than some tax codes...  it started a war, sent a message, and changed an entire culture literally forever!

Â @johnnytrigger300Â  We're also used to tuning in to a lot of accents here in the UK, which I think gives you a good ear for them. You can be in different parts of the same relatively small town and the accent will change.  You'll hear older people talk of accents even changing from a few streets away. There are hundreds of accents and dialects here not to mention 3 (4 if you count Gaelic) languages in the British Isles - about the size of Oregon! The funny thing is, the proper "English" accent is what is spoken in the Eastern United States. After the foundation of the American colonies, in the mid 1700s, what is known today as the "British accent" became a popular affectation, kind of like a cultural fad. One which never caught on in the colonies. But it stuck in Britain and the Isles.  So Americans largely speak English with the accent the British used to have before about 1750 or so.  That's also why Australians and New Zealanders have accents, but Canadians don't except the Quebecoise. They were both settled after the accent was baked in to British society. Bit mind boggling, isn't it?

I am South African and can almost COMPLETELY relate to these Britons!  That was NOT a biscuit, that was a scone! Scones (pronounced SKONS), are to be had with jam and cream, and tea! How can u put gravy on scones? That was something I could not relate to.  In South Africa, we use Worcestershire sauce, but everyone just says Worcester sauce.  South Africans defintely do fish and chips! Very commonly. And also "bangers and mash", but we don't use the word "bangers". We use "wors" (introduced by The Afrikaners, descendants of The Dutch), almost like the German "wurst".  In South Africa, every household has a kettle for tea. Its quite unheard of not to have a kettle.  Oh, and we drive on the left side of the road.  We spell the word as centre, not center.  Metre, not meter. Neighbour, not neibor. We say leh-zher, not lee-zher (when pronouncing leisure) Semi is semi (as the "i" in big). Not seh-migh. Eg: semi-circle!  And it is: Autumn, not fall. Tap, not faucet. Celcius, not faranheit. Coriander, not cilantro.

American southerner here, and i just have to defend the biscuits and gravy thing. Especially because that image was almost as unflattering as the bangers and mash meme. First of all, you havent lived until you've had a proper buttermilk biscuit. The recipe is widely available online and fairly simple, but we mostly just buy something thats prepared, ready to throw in the oven. Brands to look out for include pilsbury and banquet. Its very common to eat them plain with butter, or with cream cheese spread and jelly/jam, but the gravy is a tradition, and a personal favorite of mine. Its not a brown gravy, but a white gravy, or more accuratly simply french bechamel cream sauce, with added chunks of a specific type of ground sausage and seasoned only with salt and heafty amount of black pepper. Notably, the ground sausage is the most important ingredient of the dish, again we typically buy it already prepared, and it is easy to come by at any supermarket in the American southeast. Brands to look out for are Jimmy Dean, Country Crock, and Banquet, and the style is "country breakfast sausage." If you cant find a brand name, and wish to prepare your own, simply use ground pork seasoned with fennel, sage, crushed red pepper, brown sugar, and if course salt, pepper, onion, and only a little garlic, please dont go overboard with the garlic.  just combine the ground meat with the bechamel cream sauce, add an honestly concerning amount of black pepper, and you have a delicious country-style sausage gravy. a real gem of the Georgia-Florida-Alabama area. also we drink coffee the way brits drink tea. We drink tea too, but very differently. Its served ice cold with comical amounts of of sugar and maybe a squeeze of lemon.

British biscuit= American cookie.  American biscuit= savory scone.  The reason most Americans donâ€™t own an electric kettle is- most Americans drink coffee and own a drip coffee machine. Some do own stove top kettles.

What you call biscuits in England are called cookies here.  You also have to remember that the US is many times larger than the UK, and there are regional preferences.  The American biscuits you show are more of a southern US thing, and not  as popular in other regions.  And that picture showed sausage gravy, so the lumpy bits are pieces of sausage.  And since most Americans drink coffee, most American homes have a dedicated coffee maker, which takes the place of your kettle.   Think about it, what do yo use the kettle for other than making tea?

look up "Accent Expert Gives a Tour of U.S. Accents" from WIRED gives the history of accents. if you go to 2:11 on the vid it explains.

At first, English speakers in the colonies and England used a rhotic accent (pronouncing the "r" as in card). After the Revolutionary War, upper-class and upper-middle-class citizens in England began using non-rhotic speech (do not pronounce the "r" as in ca'd) as a way to show their social status. Thus lower class started copying the more posh way of speaking which made the different British accents. American English is more closer to what all English speakers spoke 400 years ago.

"In America they have those with gravy..."  Well, yes.   But we *also* cut them in half and have them with honey or jam. Biscuits are more versatile than *just* biscuits and gravy. I mean, if you've never had a fresh warm buttermilk biscuit torn in half horizontally with honey drizzled on the inside (face-up), you've never really "lived," have you? ;)  American "biscuits" are basically British "scones" just without the egg & sugar. So they're more a little bit buttery / flaky / savory. But, we do also have scones,  which are typically made a bit sweeter, and tend to be more dense / dried out in bakeries, for whatever reason. Whether made wrong, or what have you? ;)  Also, don't knock biscuits & gravy until you've had it. It's actually quite savoury /delicious.  It's a white cream sauce / gravy with browned ground sausage, flour [thickener], cream, cracked  black pepper, maybe some other herbs / spices. You know what's even better: you do NOT have to fill it to the brim, and boil a full quart (or more) of water.  Sounds ridiculous for most europeans, but apparently some americans dislike kettles because they are "so slow and wasteful". Well, most kettles do have a minimum as well as a maximum marker. Maximum to avoid spilling boiling water, minimum to avoid the heating elements overheating when not properly covered with water. Anything between those two lines on the kettle is just fine.  PS: yes, this was ranked as an important life hack americans learned while staying in Germany. My reaction was similar to the boys when they heard about 'muricans not having kettles. ;)

Â @ThyBinlidÂ  Not just you brits, it's the same everywhere. Be it our beloved fro...nch neighbours, us krauts, as well as czech, poles... everyone uses kettles. Well, some russians might still use samowars ... if their son didn't bring back a nice kettle from their "summer vacation"...

Â @AleaumeAndersÂ  I donâ€™t feel like the kettle is slow at all! I love that I can set it to boil and walk away and it automatically turns off when the water is ready. Itâ€™s amazing.

I, an American who always had an electric kettle growing up, learned that itâ€™s not common here thanks to those Britâ€™ish memes.  *for the same volume of water, an electric kettle is faster than a microwave

Â @AleaumeAndersÂ  How is an electric kettle slow and wasteful when it takes 1-2 min and automatically shuts off when it's boiling? Boiling water on the stove for anything other than cooking is slow and wasteful and doing it in the microwave is just barbaric lol

Â @edithputhy4948Â  Well it is, if you need one cup only, and are boiling a full 1.5 or 2l ... that was the "lifehack" I was mentioning, only boil as much as you need. I was flabbergasted ... that anyone wouldn't do so just out of common sense.
I'm an American, but only ever had a regular kettle. Of course the kettle I have now is pretty colorful, which is lovely. My parents just had a plain metal one when I was a kid.

Â @darkangel_1978Â  :D I can remember the "old" times, when my parents had a kettle for the stove.  You know the really old style, that would only start whistling once enough steam formed. Then they had the ones where you placed a "curly" iron on a cable inside the metal pot.  But since at least 20-30 years all we ever had are the simple plastic (or aluminium) pots with a hidden heating element. Much safer, quicker and less energy hungry.

Â @AleaumeAndersÂ  sadly my kettle doesn't make a noise when it goes off, but it's quite lovely, so I will forgive it. So we just keep an eye on it. Neither set of grandparents ever had kettles when I was growing up, but my maternal great grandmother sure did. I can't imagine not having a kettle. If I was without a kettle in my house, I think it would drive me crazy

Â @charliedavis8894Â  Biscuits and gravy is ubiquitous in the south, and very uncommon in the north.  Biscuits and jam or honey is weird and not common. I would put jam on a scone, not a biscuit. I grew up in the northeast, and the only thing you'd ever put on a biscuit up there is butter.

Â @BaglessUprightÂ  If you mean it's uncommon in the NE US you are probably correct.   Everywhere else it's very common.   I've had biscuits and gravy from San Diego to Seattle and all points between.   I've had it in Arizona, Nevada, Utah,  Idaho, Montana, Wyoming, South Dakota, Michigan, Ohio , you get my point. i got told (idk if itâ€™s true) that the reason americans donâ€™t have kettles because the wattage is different and having a kettle is an electrical risk!

Itâ€™s one reason why theyâ€™re not as popular as in the UK. UK sockets output 220-240volts at 13 Amps. The US sockets output 110-120 volts at 15 amps. This means that the maximum power for a UK kettle is about 2800-3000 watts where in the US the maximum power for a US kettle is about 1500-1800 watts and because of this they boil much slower.

Â @jishanbornoÂ  fry 1 lb  sausage ( American pork sausage with mild spices mixed in)cook crumbled up until browned, remove meat from skillet but leave the grease. Get that grease hot, about 2T worth , then add equal amount of flour, stir and cook the flour with the grease until it browns and it changes the fragrance, then add 20  or so ounces full fat milk ( or 50/50 evaporated milk and cold water), pour milk into skillet with flour concoction. Stir the hell out of it over med high heat until it starts to thicken, reintroduce sausage, a bit of salt and black pepper. Once itâ€™s thick enough, remove from heat and serve it on a biscuit. Itâ€™s really amazing. It also adds tremendous flavor to add some bacon grease to the sausage grease before adding flour.

Â @Linus.0823Â  proud Englishman here but unfortunately you're wrong, the American accent is probably closer to the old English accent than today's English accent(s) is. Two ways we can tell this is 1) the American and Australian accents are similar in the sense that they are both much more 'nasal' and also have that higher pitch tone everyone does when they impersonate an American or Australian.. if you think about it, the first American and Australian settlers landed in their countries around 400 and 200 years ago (400 - American, 200 Australian) so these settlers would have both taken with them something similar to what was being used in England at the time. The fact that the Australians and Americans both speak with a nasal sound and higher pitch makes it very likely that the English used to speak with a nasal sound and higher pitch. There is no explanation as to why both these accents would develop by themselves this way unless the English accent sounded much more American/ Australian back in the day.   And another way we can tell is that before there was an official spelling for words (no dictionary) people used to write how they spoke. If we read documents written from hundreds of years ago (we can even use examples from the monarchy like queen Victoria for example) even the way she wrote suggests that she spoke much more like an American than an Englishman, with stronger pronunciation of certain letters and parts of words and less focus on others.  So yes, as annoying as it is and as little as I like to admit it, the Americans actually sound more like the old English than the actual English do. Sorry to ruin the party.

@lj2539Â  This isn't fully accurate. Yes, pronunciation has evolved, and RP is now based on a single regional accent, which was never the dominant accent in the UK. Accents as well as dialects in former colonies have indeed hung on to things that were lost in the UK... but then those colonies added their own flavour too.  The American accents in particular are strongly influenced by high levels of immigration... and the lexicon and syntax reflect the fact that many settlers spoke Dutch or German as their mother tongue. Rhoticity came from the Celts (mostly Irish immigrants). Loan words like zucchini were taken from other groups....  There is no one place you can go where you'll hear English spoken in its 'original form'... (And what would that form be? Would it include the old Germanic 'thou' and its conjugations?)...  The fact is, however, that few British people today truly use RP. I did my thesis on the 'Queen's English', and my conclusion was that nobody actually spoke it.  There is no 'right version', but I'd suspect that the version that sounds closest to the 'old version' is actually spoken in the UK, some distance North of London but south of Edinburgh.

the funniest part is that what people in the US speak today is exactly how their ancestors sounded before 1800. â€‹@V1atrixxi3 Restroom came from the days of carriages bringing people to large balls from a distance, and or those that had to walk from one place in town to another to attend, upon arriving they would first go into a room to "rest" , freshen up, powder their faces( hence the other term we use, powder room ) relieve themselves if needed, and leave their coats or capes, and afterwards go into the ball itself. Even beyond those days into more modern eras, for the wealthier people a restroom in a fancy restaurant for example, would be luxurious and quite large, an attendent would be there with everything from fancy soaps, clean hand towels, to light refreshments. There would be small sofas to rest upon, and tables where ladies could freshen makeup or hair, with a separate area in the back behind doors for the toilets. So the names restroom and powder room are carry overs from those times.

Biscuits for us in the US are a type of quick bread. They can be made with Bisquick (easiest way) in less than 30 minutes. They are not sweet and we do use them with a variety of foods and at any meal. Our McDonald's, as well as other fast food chains that serve breakfast foods, have biscuits (for butter and jam), biscuit breakfast sandwiches (egg, cheese, bacon and/or sausage or with country style steak, or ham), and biscuits and gravy (from a powder mix...not great)...to name but a few options. We use them for the bread choice when making pork/beef stews or roasts. The uses for biscuits varies greatly depending on state or region as does the gravy used. I swear, Brits are like the Japanese of Europe, and Japanese like the Brits of Asia. 1. Both are island nations. 2. Both have a monarch (king and emperor). 3. Both were imperial powers, responsible for a lot of the historical atrocities in the world.  4. Both have an angrier and more drunk neighbor to their west, whom they invaded, and sadly split into two (Ireland + Northern Ireland and South Korea + North Korea). 5. Both also have a larger neighbor in the mainland (China and France), who significantly influenced their language and culture, and they share a complicated history and relationship (frenemies). 6. Both have also been raided by badass warriors (Vikings and Mongols). 7. Both had a feudal system (castles and chivalrous armored warriors (knights and samurais)). 8. Both were the first country in their continent to experience the Industrial Revolution. 9. Both are today the second-largest economy in their continent (China is first in Asia, and Germany is first in Europe). 10. Both their best known food is a fish-based dish (fish-and-chips and sushi), with some questionable dishes (stargazy pie, jellied eels, fugu, raw frog). 11. Both love their teas. 12. Both love their rock music (J-Rock and classic rock).  13. Both are known for being great at queuing. 14. Both are known for having bad teeth. 15. Both drive on the left side of the road. 16. Both like to keep their taxis looking vintage (for some strange reason). 17. Both have a weird sense of humor to most of the world. 18. Both are known for their introversion, reserve, and etiquette, which is why they are so indirect and polite. 19. Both dress either very conventional (understated, monotone, modest) or straight up funky and eccentric (nothing in between). 20. Both need their alcohol to let their personalities out.

Not me being Nigerian, who was colonized by the British, so until I was 12, I grew up saying things like: trousers, knickers, dustbin, trolley, drugs (pharmacy), etc. Then I moved abroad to the UAE and was confused when people called trousers...pants. "Aren't pants your underwear," I asked my mother. Apparently, underwear was called panties or underwear. And I couldn't bring out my "drugs" anymore, only medicine. I was already black so that made things worse. And now that I'm 20 years old, I realize my vocabulary is a strange mix of British and American English, depending on the accent I choose to use that day. If I speak with my mother-tongue, it's British English. If I speak with my white voice, it's American English. I ponder all these things as I boil water in my kettle to make some green tea.

Scones vs biscuits from an American who bakes, to settle it. TL;DR: scones and biscuits aren't the same and Americans would find it weird to put gravy on a scone, too.  British scone, per Mary Berry: mostly cold cubed butter with a little milk and some sugar, cut the butter into the flour to produce a pebble texture.  This produces small pockets of butter in the dough, which creates a moist crumble texture.  Most Americans would immediately recognize this as a "shortcake" if you stuffed it with whipped cream and fresh strawberries instead of clotted cream and jam, so we do have/make them here.  "Traditional" U.S. scone: no butter whatsoever.  All fat and moisture comes from heavy/whipping cream.  More sugar than a British scone.  The lack of butter produces a very dry crumble.  10/10 do not recommend.  Traditional "flaky" U.S. biscuit: cold grated butter and buttermilk, almost no sugar.  Cut the butter into the flour to produce a fine pebble texture, then roll the dough out, fold onto itself, roll again, etc, like making puff pastry.  This produces thin sheets of butter in between the dough that cause the finished product to flake/peel apart, kind of like a croissant but more dense.  Not noticeably sweet.  Modified "tender" U.S. biscuit: a British scone but more milk and almost no sugar.  Similar texture to a British scone but generally more moist and not noticeably sweet.  Probably a large contributor to the confusion between British scones and American biscuits.

You guys are really privileged to get to interact with those young men. If you can get past the look, Biscuits and Gravy is one of the tastiest things you'll ever eat.  When I was at Military Academy and in the Army, we had a breakfast item called S.O.S., which was typical military three letter abbreviation for Shit on a Shingle. Basically it is traditionally made with chipped  beef or hamburger, mixed with a traditional milk based country cream gravy, and served over toast (that's the shingle).  My father, who served during the Korean War period, was served the same thing. It is a staple in military "cuisine", and each new generation of soldiers discovers it.  It genuinely tastes great, and both my dad and I still make it about once a month . A very basic recipe for you lads to try at home: Ingredients 1 pound of ground beef, preferably ground chuck, and preferably with an 80% to 20% meat to fat ratio. 1 pound ground pork (optional, but it does add good flavor) 1 small to medium onion, finely diced To cloves of garlic, finely minced, or use garlic powder (not garlic salt). Course ground black pepper Salt to taste 4 to 6  heaping table spoons of all purpose flour 2 to 3 cups of whole milk (warmed in the microwave)  Optional add one can of evaporated milk (canned)  Dice your onion. In a large pot, on medium heat, crumble your ground beef and pork, and add the onion, garlic and pepper, and cook completely.  Then add the flour and stir. ( this absorbs the cooked fat and basically creates what is called a roux in culinary terms. It is,also what thicken your milk gravy. Reduce the heat to low medium, and Add the warmed milk and the can of evaporated milk, stirring frequently to prevent scorching and until the country gravy thickens ( it should basically coat a spoon like a bechemel sauce) Add salt to taste Serve over well done toast, or you can use other options like a biscuit or in England a plain scone.  it is also excellent served over  crispy French fries (chips), it creates a real contrast with the crispy fries and creamy gravy. It is reminiscent of the Canadian French fry dish called Poutine. I call it Army poutine.  Anyway, give it a try, and let the boys at your school try it. I'm pretty sure there will be some converts. I'm betting the twins will enjoy it as well. Bon Apetit

Â @sharpy1878Â  @EwanS Efc  Here, we have slightly sweet and savory scones(to choose from), but we don't put gravy on those.  American biscuits are light and fluffy inside while scones are more dense.  A warm fluffy buttermilk biscuit or two with gravy poured over is a great breakfast.  Breakfast gravy is a white gravy made with flour and milk or cream with cracked pepper and salt and sometimes cayenne or crumbles of sausage. Biscuits and Gravy in the USA is basically an unsweet flour-based bread with a cream (or milk) gravy usually with ground pork sausage meat mixed in.  It often looks nasty, but tastes delicious.  Unlike many US breakfasts which are sweet, the Biscuits and Gravy is usually a savory breakfast.  The US biscuits would probably work well with the British breakfast beans, too, instead of toast.  US biscuits are wonderful for absorbing the liquids of stews, chili, vegetable juices, gravies, etc., giving the biscuits the wonderful flavor of the foods they are being eaten with.  The biscuits on their own don't have much flavor, but they are also frequently eaten split in half with butter, jellies, honey, etc., too, if not served with the creamy sausage gravy.

About the british food vs. American food healthwise; Sure, the Brittish breakfast looks unhealthy, but as far as I can see, its mostly protein, a bit of fat, and a few carbs. American foods tend to be FAR more loaded with carbs and fat, and a surprisingly small amount of protein. I mean, even their bread is so loaded with sugar that it is not legally allowed to be sold as bread here in the EU, they'd have to classify it as cake...  Basically, the dish in the picture will keep you going, even if you have a tough physical job. All an American breakfast will do for you, is give you diabetes and heart disease.  How "healthy" something is, has nothing to do with how it looks. I could cook you a meal that'd look like an instant cardiac arrest, and it'd be some of the healthiest food you've ever eaten.

Excellent suggestion, but...  Whoever made the dish for them would have to go to "YouTube University" and watch several videos regarding how to make "Authentic Southern Biscuits and Sausage Gravy" first.  They'd also need to learn the difference between a typical British sausage and American breakfast sausage, because the two taste fairly different. The seasonings used in something like a Jimmy Dean bulk country sausage are very specific and they're what give the gravy it's distinctive "savory but not spicy" deliciousness! ğŸ˜˜ğŸ˜  I've seen a few channels from outside the US attempt to make the dish, using what they consider to be sausage and a then paired it with a "sweet" biscuit recipe, like the type used for berry shortcake and cobbler... and let's just say that it's been a disaster every time.  ğŸ˜‚ Peeling the casing off a traditional bratwurst or British "banger" and dicing it into little cubes does not give the desired result. HaHa  I've also seen recipes on YouTube for homemade American bulk breakfast sausage, which is imperative to the dish and not too difficult to make, if you have the meat grinder attachment for your KitchenAid mixer or you have a local butcher that you have a great relationship with who'll follow the process to the letter. I'm not sure if all countries have fresh ground pork shoulder in their grocery store butcher/meat department, but it must have no seasoning in it, other than maybe a bit of salt that was added in the processing.  All that to ultimately say, true Southern Biscuits and Sausage Gravy must be made with the traditional American ingredients if one wants to experience the â€real deal". This is not the type of dish where substitutions in the ingredients or preparation are a good idea.  But... if done correctly, I'm convinced that the guys would absolutely love it! ğŸ˜Š

Â @bobbiejojackson9448Â  my fathers and grandfathers cousins in the Carolinas used to make this sausage before it became commercial. As with any sausage making process, grinding the right cuts of meat is important because the fat ratios matter, but the seasoning is fairly simple. Fennel, Sage, Crushed red pepper, and the onion garlic salt and pepper. all the seasoning ratios are always to taste, ive heard stories of making a "taster" sausage first to make sure the seasonings are right before grinding the rest of the hog, but the best kept secret is the best cuts to throw in the grinder for the perfect fat ratio. Thats always the tricky part. My grandad actually lost a finger to a meat grinder.

It's faster to use what you've got, whether that's a microwave or stove, than buy an extra appliance to have to find room for as most of us have too much to begin with. PS, the most common experiment was to use 2 identical plants in the same soil, different pots and given the exact same amounts of water.  This experiment has been repeated many times with the same result.  One plant received water boiled in a microwave and cooled, the other plant received water boiled on a stove and cooled.  The microwave watered plant withered and died because the microwaved water was chemically changed.

I mean biscuits and gravy is one way biscuits are served, & not the most common. You are more likely to see them around a breakfast sandwich, or as the bread side for various meals. Biscuits in the U.S. became popular particularly in the South & South West, because it's hot, & prior to AC, yeasted breads weren't very practical. Soda breads (& corn bread which is levened with baking soda or baking powder, but is not a soda bread in the usual sense) can bake quicker, and versions of them can even be made over a stove or camp fire. One other difference is, our biscuits usually have a higher butter content.

Apart from being more coffee people, one of the main reasons that Americans don't bother with kettles is there plectrical grid. Theirs runs at 120V and 60Hz AC electricity [110-volt AC (110V)], compared to the UK's 230v 50 Hz (formerly 240V in UK, 220V in the rest of Europe). So if they do use a kettle it takes at least twice as long. They still use stovetop kettles though.

As a southerner who has had (and liked) scones. It hurts my heart everytime someone compares biscuits to scones. I feel a visceral pain ğŸ˜…. They are very different. Biscuits are soft and fluffy on the inside whereas scones are drier and more crumbly. Also biscuits are savory, scones are sweet. Which is why a biscuit can go with gravy.  And yes we eat biscuits and gravy ğŸ˜‹ but biscuits and jam/jelly are probably more common.

I just wanted to add about the tea kettles. British homes have 240W of electricity running through their homes so their kettles heat up the water fairly quickly. American homes run on 120W so it takes quite a long time. Its quicker for us to just microwave it but some people like me use the stove top to heat water.  Volts not Watts sorry.

Â @thatgirl9532Â  So, to clear up a small thing here: for most Americans, if you said "Gravy" without added context, they would imagine a brown gravy, as one would 'normally' have with a roast dinner, mashed potatoes, or other dinner dishes.   However, "biscuits and gravy" is typically a breakfast food, and it uses a sausage/cream-based gravy, (often called "country gravy") that originally arose out of a (somewhat contradictory) sense of frugality and decadence: see,  sausage is a pretty traditional American breakfast staple, so what you'd do is fry sausage, and then make a simple gravy in the left-over fat. If you had the money/resources, you would add additional protein or fat by adding milk or cream to the gravy. And if you were particularly well off, you'd have extra sausage to leave in the gravy, to add even MORE fat/protein.  Over time, cattle and milk production in America made milk very easily accessible, so everyone who grew up only getting the milk-enriched gravy sometimes could now do it ALL the time, and it became the de-facto version for specifically breakfast meals that could use gravy, like biscuits (where the added gravy lets you hide if they're a little dry), or a dish like Chicken-fried steak (a pounded and breaded beefsteak, fried, and served sauced with the gravy)  For a similar culinary progression, you can look at Spaghetti and Meatballs: Italian immigrants to America discovered beef was vastly cheaper here, and, to treat themselves, combined spaghetti in meat sauce with meatballs, forming a new, doubly meaty dish.

The acidity of buttermilk reacts with baking soda, which is a base, to create more, not less, rise than with a less acidic liquid such as milk. While itâ€™s true that buttermilkâ€™s acidity would interfere with the leavening effect of yeast, a buttermilk biscuit would never use yeast as a leavening agent. Â @IshlacorrinÂ  Your basic 3 ingredient "biscuit" is called shortbread in America, and is considered a hard cookie, not a biscuit.  An American biscuit uses your 3 ingredients as a base but is not the entire recipe.  While there are 3 ingredient American biscuits, those recipes use self-rising flour which has the baking powder in it.  Baking powder has been used in American biscuits since it was invented in 1846, before that, a combination of cream of tartar and baking soda was used and if those weren't available Americans have used potash since the early 1700s.    MelissaAK is correct, American buttermilk biscuits always have a leavening agent and are light, fluffy or flaky and delicious.  They can be eaten plain, with butter and jam, with sausage gravy or stuffed with egg, cheese and sausage, ham or bacon as a breakfast sandwich. Your basic 3 ingredients are not just the basic ingredients in biscuits but also the basic ingredients in white sauce, better known in Europe as bechamel sauce.  White sauce is the basic ingredient in the gravy for biscuits and gravy but sausage and seasonings are added and sometimes sausage or bacon fat is used instead of butter.  What the British call a biscuit isn't the same as an American biscuit (buttermilk or milk), neither are the 2 countries scones or cookies the same things.
